page.title: 08Food & Drink in a Rural Area
page.content: Eating patterns have changed since the last war for a number of reasons. Farmers no longer separate their own cream and thus much less cream is consumed. The traditional fatty pig has lost favour, while ducks, free range chickens and rabbits are no longer kept on the farm. Now most farmers' wives shop for eggs and meat like the rest of us. Old habits such as ferreting and shooting for the pot have largely disappeared and pheasants and partriges have declined with the removal of hedges and scrub. Thus most now eat less meat than in days gone by. Bottling of vegetables and fruit has been replaced by freezing and so gardeners are less bothered about a regular supply of food through the year. Country wines and home brewing are still popular although farmers no longer brew for the harvesters.
